description:
The story is centered around a small group of guerilla freedom fighters on a colonial planet named Deployer, who are known as the "Deployer 7", or "Sun Fang" team. In an unexpected coup, the elected Governor of Deployer becomes dictator and rules Deployer under martial law with the support of Earth's Federation. Fighting for independence from Earth's Federation influence, the freedom fighters begin a rebellion against the Federation's Combat Armors using a Combat Armor of their own: the Dougram.

(Source: AniDB)

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Anachronism
tags.description: Prominently features elements that are out of place in the historical period the work takes place in, particularly modern elements in a historical setting.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋良輔_(アニメ監督%29)

Originally from [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/). He is one of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s most influential figures, pioneering and evolving the "real robot" genre of anime with shows such as [Taiyou no Kiba Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/) and [Soukou Kihei Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋良輔_(アニメ監督%29)

Originally from [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/). He is one of [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s most influential figures, pioneering and evolving the "real robot" genre of anime with shows such as [Taiyou no Kiba Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/) and [Soukou Kihei Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/).

Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神田武幸)

Passed away suddenly in 1996. The final episode of The 08th MS Team, the movie Miller's Report and the first episode of Ginga Hyouryuu Vifam 13 were all dedicated in his memory.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神田武幸)

Passed away suddenly in 1996. The final episode of The 08th MS Team, the movie Miller's Report and the first episode of Ginga Hyouryuu Vifam 13 were all dedicated in his memory.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/8tabe5817) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuyoshi_Yatabe) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷田部勝義)

Yatabe Katsuyoshi is a Japanese screenwriter and director.     

After graduating he joined the Department of Arts at Nihon Daigaku in 1975. In 1978 he joined Ad Cosmo but felt that as subcontractor there would be no real productions done and thus went on to join Sunrise in 1979. There he learned under [Tomino Yoshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/97337) and [Takahashi Ryousuke](https://anilist.co/staff/100957) before becoming freelancer.

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷口守泰)

A veteran animator with a career spanning nearly 60 years.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉川惣司)

A fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, when Yoshikawa was a sophomore in high school, he saw a "Mushi Production's first batch of animators wanted" news article and applied for the job, which led him to enter the anime industry. He was planning to go to art college, but was invited to join Mushi Pro, so he quit high school and joined the company. He participated as an animator for the first [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/) series. In 1967, he participated in the founding of _Art Fresh with Gisaburou Sugii and Osamu Dezaki_. After working as an animator on Mushi Production's [Gokuu no Daibouken](https://anilist.co/anime/2687/), which Art Fresh participated in, he worked as a freelance animator before becoming a senior director and board member of Dyna-Method Inc.

In addition to serving as episode director, storyboard artist and writer, he also worked as a director. He has participated in [Tensai Bakabon](https://anilist.co/anime/6468/), [Star of the Giants](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/), [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), [Moomin](https://anilist.co/anime/8234/), [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/), [Invincible Super Man Zambot 3](https://anilist.co/anime/2200/), [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/).

In addition to anime, he created, wrote and directed Star Guardian with Airship Theater Company, wrote the screenplays for Tanoshii Moomin Ikka and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs and wrote and directed The Wizard of Oz. It all started when he was asked by director [Masaaki Oosumi](https://anilist.co/staff/122102/) to help with the screenplay of Aladdin for Airship Theater Company's Aladdin when he was working on the TV adaptation of Moomin. In addition, he has worked on commercials, events, performances and novels. He has been a fan of science fiction since he read Shounen Shoujo Sekai Kagaku Bouken Zenshuu by Kodansha when he was a kid.

One of the reasons that the 100th episode of the [Kirby: Right Back at Ya!](https://anilist.co/anime/2390/) anime contained some problems, inconsistencies, and heavy-handedness in the plot and development is that Yoshikawa, who wrote the final episode, learned that his wife was in critical condition at the time and had to rush through the script and leave it in incomplete form in order to be present for her dying moments.

[Yasuo Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/) cited in an interview for the Lupin III Perfect Book: Complete Collector's Edition, that [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), Osamu Dezaki, and Yoshikawa as representative members of the Japanese anime world.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉川惣司)

A fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s works, when Yoshikawa was a sophomore in high school, he saw a "Mushi Production's first batch of animators wanted" news article and applied for the job, which led him to enter the anime industry. He was planning to go to art college, but was invited to join Mushi Pro, so he quit high school and joined the company. He participated as an animator for the first [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/) series. In 1967, he participated in the founding of _Art Fresh with Gisaburou Sugii and Osamu Dezaki_. After working as an animator on Mushi Production's [Gokuu no Daibouken](https://anilist.co/anime/2687/), which Art Fresh participated in, he worked as a freelance animator before becoming a senior director and board member of Dyna-Method Inc.

In addition to serving as episode director, storyboard artist and writer, he also worked as a director. He has participated in [Tensai Bakabon](https://anilist.co/anime/6468/), [Star of the Giants](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/), [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), [Moomin](https://anilist.co/anime/8234/), [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/), [Invincible Super Man Zambot 3](https://anilist.co/anime/2200/), [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), and [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/).

In addition to anime, he created, wrote and directed Star Guardian with Airship Theater Company, wrote the screenplays for Tanoshii Moomin Ikka and Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs and wrote and directed The Wizard of Oz. It all started when he was asked by director [Masaaki Oosumi](https://anilist.co/staff/122102/) to help with the screenplay of Aladdin for Airship Theater Company's Aladdin when he was working on the TV adaptation of Moomin. In addition, he has worked on commercials, events, performances and novels. He has been a fan of science fiction since he read Shounen Shoujo Sekai Kagaku Bouken Zenshuu by Kodansha when he was a kid.

One of the reasons that the 100th episode of the [Kirby: Right Back at Ya!](https://anilist.co/anime/2390/) anime contained some problems, inconsistencies, and heavy-handedness in the plot and development is that Yoshikawa, who wrote the final episode, learned that his wife was in critical condition at the time and had to rush through the script and leave it in incomplete form in order to be present for her dying moments.

[Yasuo Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/136873/) cited in an interview for the Lupin III Perfect Book: Complete Collector's Edition, that [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), Osamu Dezaki, and Yoshikawa as representative members of the Japanese anime world.

(Source: Wikipedia)

__Graduated:__ Tokyo Zokei University

Takizawa Toshifumi was a Japanese director, episode director and storyboard artist.

After he graduated Tokyo Zokei University, he got to work at Tokyo Animation Film, where he worked as part of a photography team. In later years he started working for Shin-Ei Douga, where he was a production assistant. After he started working at Nippon Sunrise, he became a director, giving his debut in 1985 with the Dirty Pair TV series. He continued working as a director afterwards, but as a freelancer instead.

He was a line director on the Ideon Be Invoked film, he was also involved in the Votoms series and has directed Gonzo's TV adaption of Kurosawa's epic Samurai 7 film, which he did in 2004.

Toshifumi passed away on June 22, 2015 from esophageal cancer. He was 61 years old when he died, and up until that point he would still be doing his ordinary activities like driving his car and walking his dog.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/寺田憲史)

Terada's more notable works include writing the first three games of the Final Fantasy series. He also worked on Batman: Dark Tomorrow, created the concept for the Sega CD game Dark Wizard, and was the main script writer for the [Kimagure Orange Road](https://anilist.co/anime/1087/) series among other things.

Takeichi Masahisa is a Japanese composer and arranger.
